study.description: A Study is a container for a sequencing investigation that may comprise multiple experiments. The Study has an overall goal, but is otherwise minimally defined in the SRA.  A Study is composed of a descriptor, zero or more experiments, and zero or more analyses. The submitter may decorate the Study with web links and properties.

fields.name: alias
fields.description: Unique identificator for a study. This is used to link experiments to the study.

fields.name: title
fields.description: Title of the study as would be used in a publication.

fields.name: study_type
fields.description: The STUDY_TYPE presents a controlled vocabulary for expressing the overall purpose of the study.

fields.name: new_study_type
fields.description: Optional if 'study_type' is not 'other'. To propose a new term, select Other and enter a new study type.

fields.name: study_abstract
fields.description: Briefly describes the goals, purpose, and scope of the Study.  This need not be listed if it can be inherited from a referenced publication.

experiment.description: An experiment object serves as a metadata record encapsulating essential details about a sequencing experiment, including the experimental design, sequencing type, and relevant parameters. This information enhances the interpretation and contextual understanding of nucleotide sequences submitted to the archive.

fields.name: alias
fields.description: Unique identificator for each experiment. This is used to link runs to experiments.

fields.name: title
fields.description: Short text that can be used to call out experiment records in searches or in displays. This element is technically optional but should be used for all new records.

fields.name: study_alias
fields.description: Identifies the parent study. (From study metadata)

fields.name: sample_alias
fields.description: (From sample metadata)

fields.name: design_description
fields.description: Goal and setup of the individual library including library was constructed.

fields.name: library_name
fields.description: The submitter's name for this library.

fields.name: library_strategy
fields.description: Sequencing technique intended for this library.

fields.name: library_source
fields.description: The LIBRARY_SOURCE specifies the type of source material that is being sequenced.

fields.name: library_selection
fields.description: Method used to enrich the target in the sequence library preparation

fields.name: library_layout
fields.description: LIBRARY_LAYOUT specifies whether to expect single, paired, or other configuration of reads. In the case of paired reads, information about the relative distance and orientation is specified.

fields.name: insert_size
fields.description: Insert size for paired reads

fields.name: library_construction_protocol
fields.description: Free form text describing the protocol by which the sequencing library was constructed.

fields.name: platform
fields.description: The PLATFORM record selects which sequencing platform and platform-specific runtime parameters. This will be determined by the Center. optional if 'instrument_model' is provided.

fields.name: instrument_model
fields.description: Model of the sequencing instrument.

run.description: A run contains a group of reads generated for a particular experiment.

fields.name: alias
fields.description: Unique identificator for each run.

fields.name: experiment_alias
fields.description: From_experiment_metadata

fields.name: file_name
fields.description: The name or relative pathname of a run data file.

fields.name: file_format
fields.description: The run data file model.

sample.description: A Sample defines an isolate of sequenceable material upon which sequencing experiments can be based.  The Sample object may be a surrogate for taxonomy accession or an anonymized individual identifier.  Or, it may fully specify provenance and isolation method of the starting material.

fields.name: alias
fields.description: Unique identificator for each sample.

fields.name: title
fields.description: Short text that can be used to call out sample records in search results or in displays.

fields.name: taxon_id
fields.description: NCBI Taxonomy Identifier.  This is appropriate for individual organisms and some environmental samples.

fields.name: scientific_name
fields.description: Scientific name of sample that distinguishes its taxonomy.  Please use a name or synonym that is tracked in the INSDC Taxonomy database. Also, this field can be used to confirm the TAXON_ID setting.

fields.name: common_name
fields.description: GenBank common name of the organism.  Examples: human, mouse.

fields.name: sample_description
fields.description: Free-form text describing the sample, its origin, and its method of isolation.

fields.name: project name
fields.description: Name of the project within which the sequencing was organized

fields.name: sample collection device
fields.description: The device used to collect an environmental sample. It is recommended to use terms listed under environmental sampling device (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO) and/or terms listed under specimen collection device (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/GENEPIO_0002094).

fields.name: sample collection method
fields.description: The method employed for collecting the sample. Can be provided in the form of a PMID, DOI, url or text.

fields.name: sample storage location
fields.description: Location at which sample was stored, usually name of a specific freezer/room. Indicate the location name.

fields.name: sample storage device
fields.description: The container used to store the sample. This field accepts terms listed under container (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/NCIT_C43186). If the proper descriptor is not listed please use text to describe the storage device.

fields.name: sample storage conditions
fields.description: Conditions at which sample was stored, usually storage temperature, duration and location. In soil context: Explain how and for how long the soil sample was stored before DNA extraction (fresh/frozen/other).

fields.name: collection date
fields.description: The date the sample was collected with the intention of sequencing, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid ISO8601 compliant times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008.
fields.regex: (^[12][0-9]{3}(-(0[1-9]|1[0-2])(-(0[1-9]|[12][0-9]|3[01])(T[0-9]{2}:[0-9]{2}(:[0-9]{2})?Z?([+-][0-9]{1,2})?)?)?)?(/[0-9]{4}(-[0-9]{2}(-[0-9]{2}(T[0-9]{2}:[0-9]{2}(:[0-9]{2})?Z?([+-][0-9]{1,2})?)?)?)?)?$)|(^not applicable$)|(^not collected$)|(^not provided$)|(^restricted access$)|(^missing: control sample$)|(^missing: sample group$)|(^missing: synthetic construct$)|(^missing: lab stock$)|(^missing: third party data$)|(^missing: data agreement established pre-2023$)|(^missing: endangered species$)|(^missing: human-identifiable$)|(^missing$)

fields.name: geographic location (region and locality)
fields.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific region name followed by the locality name.

fields.name: geographic location (latitude)
fields.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system
fields.regex: (^[+-]?[0-9]+.?[0-9]{0,8}$)|(^not applicable$)|(^not collected$)|(^not provided$)|(^restricted access$)|(^missing: control sample$)|(^missing: sample group$)|(^missing: synthetic construct$)|(^missing: lab stock$)|(^missing: third party data$)|(^missing: data agreement established pre-2023$)|(^missing: endangered species$)|(^missing: human-identifiable$)|(^missing$)

fields.name: geographic location (longitude)
fields.description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system
fields.regex: (^[+-]?[0-9]+.?[0-9]{0,8}$)|(^not applicable$)|(^not collected$)|(^not provided$)|(^restricted access$)|(^missing: control sample$)|(^missing: sample group$)|(^missing: synthetic construct$)|(^missing: lab stock$)|(^missing: third party data$)|(^missing: data agreement established pre-2023$)|(^missing: endangered species$)|(^missing: human-identifiable$)|(^missing$)

fields.name: broad-scale environmental context
fields.description: Report the major environmental system the sample or specimen came from. The system(s) identified should have a coarse spatial grain, to provide the general environmental context of where the sampling was done (e.g. in the desert or a rainforest). We recommend using subclasses of EnvO’s biome class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00000428. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.

fields.name: local environmental context
fields.description: Report the entity or entities which are in the sample or specimen’s local vicinity and which you believe have significant causal influences on your sample or specimen. We recommend using EnvO terms which are of smaller spatial grain than your entry for "broad-scale environmental context". Terms, such as anatomical sites, from other OBO Library ontologies which interoperate with EnvO (e.g. UBERON) are accepted in this field. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.

fields.name: environmental medium
fields.description: Report the environmental material(s) immediately surrounding the sample or specimen at the time of sampling. We recommend using subclasses of 'environmental material' (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00010483). EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS . Terms from other OBO ontologies are permissible as long as they reference mass/volume nouns (e.g. air, water, blood) and not discrete, countable entities (e.g. a tree, a leaf, a table top).

fields.name: elevation
fields.description: The elevation of the sampling site as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.
fields.regex: ([+-]?(0|((0\.)|([1-9][0-9]*\.?))[0-9]*)([Ee][+-]?[0-9]+)?)|((^not applicable$)|(^not collected$)|(^not provided$)|(^restricted access$)|(^missing: control sample$)|(^missing: sample group$)|(^missing: synthetic construct$)|(^missing: lab stock$)|(^missing: third party data$)|(^missing: data agreement established pre-2023$)|(^missing: endangered species$)|(^missing: human-identifiable$)|(^missing$))

fields.name: collected_by
fields.description: name of persons or institute who collected the specimen

fields.name: geographic location (country and/or sea)
fields.description: The geographical origin of where the sample was collected from, with the intention of sequencing, as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html).
cv: South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands

fields.name: depth
fields.description: The vertical distance below local surface, e.g. for sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface, respectively. Depth can be reported as an interval for subsurface samples.
fields.regex: ((0|((0\.)|([1-9][0-9]*\.?))[0-9]*)([Ee][+-]?[0-9]+)?)|((^not applicable$)|(^not collected$)|(^not provided$)|(^restricted access$)|(^missing: control sample$)|(^missing: sample group$)|(^missing: synthetic construct$)|(^missing: lab stock$)|(^missing: third party data$)|(^missing: data agreement established pre-2023$)|(^missing: endangered species$)|(^missing: human-identifiable$)|(^missing$))

fields.name: total depth of water column
fields.description: measurement of total depth of water column

fields.name: source material identifiers
fields.description: A unique identifier assigned to a material sample (as defined by http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/materialSampleID, and as opposed to a particular digital record of a material sample) used for extracting nucleic acids, and subsequent sequencing. The identifier can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. The INSDC qualifiers /specimen_voucher, /bio_material, or /culture_collection may or may not share the same value as the source_mat_id field. For instance, the /specimen_voucher qualifier and source_mat_id may both contain 'UAM:Herps:14' , referring to both the specimen voucher and sampled tissue with the same identifier. However, the /culture_collection qualifier may refer to a value from an initial culture (e.g. ATCC:11775) while source_mat_id would refer to an identifier from some derived culture from which the nucleic acids were extracted (e.g. xatc123 or ark:/2154/R2).

fields.name: negative control status
fields.description: Is this sample a negative control?

fields.name: negative control of
fields.description: Reference to the sample(s) for which the negative control was used. The referenced samples should already be registered in INSDC. This should be formatted as one of the following. A single sample e.g. ERSxxxxxx OR a comma separated list e.g. ERSxxxxxx,ERSxxxxxx OR a range e.g. ERSxxxxxx-ERSxxxxxx

fields.name: negative control type
fields.description: The substance or equipment used as a negative control in an investigation

fields.name: sample volume or weight for DNA extraction
fields.description: Volume (ml) or mass (g) of total collected sample processed for DNA extraction. Note: total sample collected should be entered under the term 'sample size'.

fields.name: nucleic acid extraction
fields.description: A link to a literature reference, electronic resource or a standard operating procedure (SOP), that describes the material separation to recover the nucleic acid fraction from a sample

fields.name: nucleic acid extraction kit
fields.description: The name of the extraction kit used to recover the nucleic acid fraction of an input material is performed.

fields.name: nucleic acid extraction date
fields.description: The date when the nucleic acid extraction was started from the sample material. In case no exact time is available, the date can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008; Except: 2008-01; 2008 all are ISO8601 compliant

fields.name: damage treatment
fields.description: Indication of whether characteristic ancient DNA damage has been altered or removed from a DNA extract in a laboratory

fields.name: master core sample id
fields.description: A Master ID is the ID of an arbitrary sized set of field samples that acts as a single continuous sample (e.g. a set of correlated cores).

fields.name: sample age range youngest limit
fields.description: The youngest possible age of the sample. Youngest refers to the time closest to present day. If a sample has only a single age value, the value from samp age range oldest limit can be repeated Sample age refers to a period of time in the past, such as when an organism was living and then died, not the biological age.

fields.name: sample age range oldest limit
fields.description: The oldest possible age of the sample. Oldest refers to the time furthest from present day. If a sample has only a single age value, the value from samp age range youngest limit can be repeated. Sample age refers to a period of time in the past, such as when an organism was living and then died, not the biological age.

fields.name: sample age inference method
fields.description: The method used to infer the sample age. This corresponds to a fixed list of most commonly used dating methods, such as 14C, OSL, stratigraphic inference, historical records, other etc. If the method is not in the list, please provide a description in samp_age_range_inference_description.

fields.name: sample age inference description
fields.description: Additional general information about the inference method used to infer the sample age that can be useful for understanding how the sample age was estimated. This can be things such as whether radiocarbon age estimated on AMS or conventional radiocarbon dating, or which calibration confidence interval was used. It can also be used to describe what artefacts were used to age the stratigraphic layer of historical contexts.

fields.name: host body preservation state
fields.description: Description of the state of the sampled (ancient) organism/host as originally preserved in the burial environment, e.g. if the the sample was artificially or naturally (fully/partially) mummified at the time of death.

fields.name: cultural era
fields.description: The cultural era approximating the period in which the individual lived from https://chronontology.dainst.org/ or PeriodO if possible. If not available, follow INSDC standard for reporting missing data (https://www.insdc.org/submitting-standards/missing-value-reporting/).

fields.name: palaeopathology status
fields.description: Describe briefly any relevant palaeopathological or health-related observations of the remains of the individual under study.

fields.name: sample decontamination pretreatment
fields.description: Method(s) employed for surface decontamination of samples of external modern DNA; Treatment used on the samples. Depends on the sample type. More relevant for bones than environmental samples. E.g. buffers, EDTA, etc.

fields.name: geological epoch
fields.description: Geological age of source sediment (Additional info: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Period_(geology)).

fields.name: past broad-scale environmental context
fields.description: Report the major environmental system the sample or specimen likely from when originally laid down. The system(s) identified should have a coarse spatial grain, to provide the general environmental context of where the sampling was done (e.g. in the desert or a rainforest). We recommend using subclasses of EnvO’s biome class: http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00000428. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.

fields.name: recovery date
fields.description: Date of excavation or retrieval from burial or depositional context, if known. In case no exact time is available, the date can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008; Except: 2008-01; 2008 all are ISO8601 compliant. If excavations were done during a longer period, report its midpoint at a month or year level.

fields.name: preservational treatment
fields.description: Description of any treatment applied to samples for the purpose of maximising collection preservation that may influence downstream DNA recovery or library construction, such as storage fluid or reconstructive glue

fields.name: sample composed of
fields.description: Reference to sample(s) that are part of a sample, for example when samples are pooled for analysis or when a group of samples corresponds to a higher level sample. The referenced sample(s) should already be registered in INSDC. This should be formatted as one of the following. A single sample e.g. ERSxxxxxx OR a comma separated list e.g. ERSxxxxxx,ERSxxxxxx

fields.name: collecting institution
fields.description: Name of the institution to which the person collecting the specimen belongs. Format: Institute Name, Institute Address

fields.name: past local environmental context
fields.description: Report the entity or entities which are in the sample or specimen’s local vicinity, likely from when originally laid down and which you believe have significant causal influences on your sample or specimen. We recommend using EnvO terms which are of smaller spatial grain than your entry for "broad-scale environmental context". Terms, such as anatomical sites, from other OBO Library ontologies which interoperate with EnvO (e.g. UBERON) are accepted in this field. EnvO documentation about how to use the field: https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/wiki/Using-ENVO-with-MIxS.

fields.name: sample same as
fields.description: Reference to sample(s) that are equivalent. The referenced sample(s) should already be registered in INSDC. This should be formatted as one of the following. A single sample e.g. ERSxxxxxx OR a comma separated list e.g. ERSxxxxxx,ERSxxxxxx

fields.name: sample derived from
fields.description: Reference to parental sample(s) or original run(s) that the assembly is derived from. The referenced samples or runs should already be registered in INSDC. This should be formatted as one of the following. A single sample/run e.g. ERSxxxxxx OR a comma separated list e.g. ERSxxxxxx,ERSxxxxxx OR a range e.g. ERSxxxxxx-ERSxxxxxx

fields.name: sample coordinator
fields.description: The name of the sample coordinator.

fields.name: sample coordinator affiliation
fields.description: The university, institution, or society affiliation of the sample coordinator.

fields.name: sample material type
fields.description: The type of material from which the sample was obtained. For the Hydrocarbon package, samples include types like core, rock trimmings, drill cuttings, piping section, coupon, pigging debris, solid deposit, produced fluid, produced water, injected water, swabs, etc. For the Food Package, samples are usually categorized as food, body products or tissues, or environmental material. This field accepts terms listed under environmental specimen (http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/GENEPIO_0001246).
